title: Should I settle with cashcall before they try to serve me? Or is it too late? They don't know where I live.
question: I had a cashcall loan that I have defaulted on. I received letters to settle but I ignored them. Today my mom was approached by a gentleman asking for me but my mom told him I don't live there any more (which I don't). I am getting a little nervous that eventually they will find out where I live and serve me. Should I try to settle with them? Is it too late to settle? Will I owe attorneys' fees at this point ( I am sure they have their own legal department)? What should I do??
answers: Cashcall may have violated your rights under FDCPA/RFDCPA. You're welcome to contact me for a free consultation, or you can contact any consumer rights attorney. Most consumer rights attorneys will evaluate your case free of charge because of the statute's fee-shifting provision. I can be reached by e-mail at arash@pricelawgroup.com.

Check the index in the clerk's office of the county courthouse to see whether your name appears as a defendant in such a lawsuit. If not, the person who approached your mother was not a process server (because the court has yet to issue a Summons). If so, the debt collector is violating federal law by communicating with a third party (your mother) in an attempt to collect a debt from you.

Do not worry took much about being sued, unless you have the money. A civil judgment only allows a creditor to garnish wages or levy on a bank account, if the creditor knows where to look. Get legal advise before communicating with them.
consult a local attorney to review your options if you are served with a debt collection lawsuit.

If you are indeed served with a lawsuit, you should consult with an attorney before approaching the creditor for settlement. An attorney can help identify certain defenses that might reduce or eliminate your liability to the creditor. You should seek out a local debt relief, consumer attorney, or bankruptcy attorney.

If they have filed a debt collection lawsuit, then you can settle it or review the video on the home page of my website to know your options. Also, I have three legal guides on Avvo, the first of which is linked, below. I also linked below my blog on how much to offer. These companies are so aggressive that I think you will not find them willing to work with you, unless you have the money to pay most of it right away. You may need to hire an attorney to represent you in the collection case and to see if he/she can get it settled on more reasonable terms.

If you don't settle with the creditor, then the debt will most likely be sold to another debt collection agency, such as GCFS or Account Management, which will use their in house lawyers to sue you, if you were not yet sued. I don't believe that the creditor will sue you on this debt, so if you were not contacted by a debt collection agency, then they probably have not sold the debt to be enforced by an outside collector. They will try to add attorneys fees and probably interest, from what I have seen, if they file a lawsuit in court. My office provides free consultations.

Robert Stempler

It is very likely that CashCall sold your loan to a debt buyer, which may make the debt noncollectable in certain circumstances. Once you obtain a copy of the Complaint, through being served or otherwise, you should consult with an experienced collection defense attorney immediately.
